title: Policies
content:
This page gives information on policies and how to edit, create, and view them.

Overview

A policy contains a set of patches that you can apply to one or more Configuration Items (CIs) or a set of vulnerabilities that you want to fix. You can fix the vulnerabilities if there are patches available for them.

Lifecycle of policies

Policies have a pre-defined workflow representing the lifecycle of every instance within Automation Center. A policy has the following metaphases:

  • Draft
  • Definition
  • Active
  • Retired

The lifecycle of a policy has the following transition phases:

policy transitions
Transition phase Transition type Description
New > Define Automatic When you fill in the name, the phase moves from New to Define.
Define > Approve Manual This identifies that there is no default approval plan and moves a policy automatically from Define to Active phase.
Approve > Define Manual/ Automatic Definition not approved.
Approve > Active Automatic Definition approved.
Active > Suspend Manual Suspend policy until you can approve changes to the rules.
Suspend > Active Manual Suspend policy until you can approve changes to the rules.
* > Retire Manual No active policy implementations reference it.

Draft

The Draft metaphase contains the following phase:

New: Initial phase for a newly created policy, until the instance has the required information.

Definition

The Definition metaphase contains the following phase:

  • Define: Defined policy rules.
  • Approve: Policy is ready for the approval process.

Active

The Active metaphase contains the following phases:

  • Action: Approved policy for use. Can create policy implementations from it. You can't change the rules.
  • Superseded: Policy suspends to change the rules. You can't create policy implementations from it.

Retired

The Retired metaphase contains the following phase:

Retire: Policy no longer of interest. You can't create policy implementations from it.

View policies

To view the policies:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build>Vulnerability & Remediation>Policies.
  2. To view the full details of a policy, navigate to the details page by clicking the entity’s ID.

Filters

Filters help you filter record lists or define filters for a report. To create a filter, see Filters - Service Management..

Policy details

The policy details contain the following tabs:

General tab

Contains the general information on the policy. The following fields displayed in the General tab are:

general tab
Policy details Description
Name The name of the policy.
Description The description of the policy.
Owner¹ The person responsible for dealing with the policy.
Owning Group¹ The group responsible for dealing with the policy.

¹ If Owner and Owning Group are not visible (for example, in environments upgraded from 24.3), a user with access to Studio must change the Forms for each entity to make the fields visible.

Workflow tab

Shows the policy instance’s current phase within the lifecycle.

Vulnerabilities tab

Add vulnerabilities to a created policy and ensure that the corresponding patches are populated.

Displays the list of user-provided vulnerabilities that the policy will remediate if patches are available.

Patches tab

The patches tab displays the following details:

Patches tab
Section Description
Patches added directly The patches selected by the users for policy application.
Patches inherited from selected vulnerabilities The patches required to fix the vulnerabilities found in the Vulnerabilities tab. In the patch details, the number of vulnerabilities column represents the vulnerabilities fixed by the patch. Selecting the number of vulnerabilities displays a list containing those vulnerabilities.

Discussions tab

Displays discussions related to the policy instance.

History tab

Shows the change history of the policy instance.

Create a policy

To create a new policy:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build>Vulnerability & Remediation>Policies.
  2. Click on the Policies page.
  3. Give the following details on the New Policy page under Policy Details:
    • Name: Mandatory. Type a unique name for the policy.
    • Description: Optional. Enter a description for the policy.
  4. Click Save.

Edit a policy

You can edit the policy individually from the Policy Details page, or in bulk by selecting multiple policies.

You can change the lists of vulnerabilities and patches when the policy is in Define or Suspend phases.

You can change the lists of vulnerabilities and patches when the policy is in Define or Suspend phases.

To edit the policy individually:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build>Vulnerability & Remediation>Policies.
  2. Select a Policy. The Policy Details page opens.
  3. Edit the Name and Description under the General tab.
  4. Click Save.

To edit policies in bulk:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build>Vulnerability & Remediation>Policies.
  2. Select the multiple policies you want to edit.
  3. On the right-hand side under Fields, click Add Field. This displays all the policy fields that you can edit, such as Name, Description, Data domains, Display Label, Owner, and Owner Group.
  4. Select the field and make the changes under New value to assign.
  5. Click Update.
